item.title: Roy Moore, Donald Trump, Saudi Arabia: Your Weekend Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
item.dc:creator: LOUIS LUCERO II and LANCE BOOTH

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: North Korea, Saudi Arabia, Manila: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Security Breach and Spilled Secrets Have Shaken the N.S.A. to Its Core
item.media:description: Jake Williams, a former member of the National Security Agency’s hacking unit. The Shadow Brokers, a mysterious group that obtained N.S.A. cybertools, identified his work for the agency on Twitter.
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.description: A serial leak of the agency’s cyberweapons has damaged morale, slowed intelligence operations and resulted in hacking attacks on businesses and civilians worldwide.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE, NICOLE PERLROTH and DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: In ‘Watershed Moment,’ YouTube Blocks Extremist Cleric’s Message
item.media:description: A search of YouTube today for the cleric Anwar al-Awlaki turns up just 18,600 videos, down from more than 70,000 this fall, and the vast majority are news reports about him, debates over the legality of his killing, refutations of his work by scholars or other material about him, rather than his jihadist propaganda.
item.description: The site has largely removed videos of Anwar al-Awlaki, Al Qaeda’s leading voice in English before his death by drone — and after, when he became a jihadist hero.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Trump Team Begins Drafting Middle East Peace Plan
item.media:description: President Trump with Jared Kushner, his son-in-law and a senior adviser, at the White House in July. Mr. Kushner is leading efforts to broker a Middle East peace deal.
item.description: Led by the president’s son-in-law, Jared Kushner, the White House team hopes to develop an American blueprint for resolving Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: After a Disciplined Week in Asia, Trump Unloads on Critics
item.media:description: President Trump with President Tran Dai Quang of Vietnam at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi.
item.description: In a stream of tweets, he called those raising questions about Russia “haters and fools” and said he could call North Korea’s leader “short and fat.”
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Duterte Warms to Trump, but Keeps His Focus on China
item.media:description: President Trump, left, with President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines and his partner, Cielito Avencana, in Manila on Sunday at a dinner honoring the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.
item.description: The leader of the Philippines is “talking as friends” with the American president, but his long-term goal is a closer relationship with the Chinese.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK and FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Trump Is Rapidly Reshaping the Judiciary. Here’s How.
item.media:description: Amul R. Thapar was confirmed to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in May, a month after his Senate Judiciary Committee confirmation hearing.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: Republican lawyers and lawmakers are working together to install conservative judges on the influential federal appeals courts at a clip not seen in decades.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Trump Nominee for Federal Judgeship Has Never Tried a Case
item.media:description: Brett Talley, a deputy assistant attorney general at the Justice Department, has been approved for a lifetime federal district judgeship by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
item.description: The nominee, Brett Talley, was approved by a Senate committee despite his unanimous “not qualified” rating from the American Bar Association.
item.dc:creator: VIVIAN WANG

item.title: Appeal Offers Hope for Newtown Families in Suit Against Gun Companies
item.media:description: David and Francine Wheeler, whose 6-year-old son Benjamin was killed in the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre, are plaintiffs in a lawsuit against the manufacturer of the weapon used in the mass killing.
item.description: The lawsuit brought by families of people killed at Sandy Hook relies on a novel strategy in attempt to hold gun companies responsible for the 2012 attack.
item.dc:creator: RICK ROJAS and KRISTIN HUSSEY

item.title: Welcoming Worshipers With Open Arms and Concealed Ones, Too
item.media:description: The Rev. John Darsey of Redeemer Church of Madison in Madison, Ga., which has multiple layers of armed security.
item.media:credit: Kevin D. Liles for The New York Times
item.description: After the massacre of 26 people at a small church in Texas, houses of worship are rethinking security plans and weighing them against the need to keep open doors.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN and RICHARD FAUSSET

item.title: Roy Moore, Alabama Senate Candidate Under Siege, Tries to Discredit Accusers
item.media:description: Roy Moore denied allegations of sexual misconduct at a Veterans Day event in Vestavia Hills, Ala.
item.description: Mr. Moore criticized the women who accused him of misconduct, and in a blow to Republican leaders, the governor refused to delay the election.
item.dc:creator: ALAN BLINDER and JONATHAN MARTIN

item.title: Republicans Try to Block Moore’s Path as Candidate Denies Sexual Misconduct
item.media:description: Roy S. Moore, the Republican candidate for Senate in Alabama, visited the Capitol last month to meet with members of his party.
item.description: Republican leaders are searching for a way to block Roy Moore’s path to the Senate, but the jurist remains defiant over charges that he made advances on teens.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MARTIN and ALEXANDER BURNS

item.title: Opinion: Why Christians Must Support Gun Control
item.media:description: A man visited a memorial of crosses in Sutherland Springs, Tex., last week.
item.description: Machines regularly used to kill innocent people violate the core of our faith.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PARKER

item.title: Opinion: Can My Children Be Friends With White People?
item.description: The rise of Donald Trump has broken bonds on all sides. But for people of color the stakes are different.
item.dc:creator: EKOW N. YANKAH

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Swine of Conservatism
item.media:description: Roy Moore speaks at a rally in Fairhope, Ala., in September.
item.description: Roy Moore and the distinctive predators of cultural conservatism.
item.dc:creator: ROSS DOUTHAT

item.title: Opinion: Being a Female Comic in Louis C.K.’s World
item.media:credit: Christian Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: The calculated risks of a life in comedy.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE KILMARTIN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Jesus’ Parents and Roy Moore’s Gall
item.description: How selectively and hypocritically some Christians deploy the Bible.
item.dc:creator: FRANK BRUNI

item.title: Opinion: The Power of the Courts Is Messing Up Politics
item.media:description: The United States Supreme Court.
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.description: Swollen beyond constitutional recognition, they distort the way elections are contested.
item.dc:creator: GREG WEINER

item.title: Sporting: How the ‘Shalane Flanagan Effect’ Works
item.media:description: Shalane Flanagan celebrated winning the New York City Marathon in Central Park on November 5.
item.description: She does not just talk about elevating her fellow women runners; she elevates them. And they win.
item.dc:creator: LINDSAY CROUSE

item.title: In Barcelona, Rajoy Calls for Record Turnout to Defeat Secessionism
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy of Spain at a rally on Sunday in Barcelona.
item.description: In his first visit to Catalonia since taking control of the restive region, the Spanish prime minister urged Catalans to vote next month for a return to “normality.”
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: With Iraqi-Kurdish Talks Stalled, Phone Diplomacy Averts New Clashes
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces last month fired a rocket launcher at Kurdish pesh merga positions near the Fish Khabbour border crossings with Turkey and Syria.
item.description: Informal talks continue amid public acrimony, but the precise roles of some of the participants are elusive. So is a breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET COKER
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Pakistani Cleric’s Supporters Block an Entrance to Islamabad
item.media:description: Pakistanis prayed in Islamabad on Friday during a protest to demand the removal of the country’s law minister.
item.description: Protesters led by the firebrand Khadim Hussain Rizvi staged a sit-in to demand the resignation of the country’s law minister and strict adherence to blasphemy laws.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Slovenian President Appears to Be on Track to Win Second Term
item.media:description: President Borut Pahor, left, and his opponent, Marjan Sarec, at a debate in Ljubljana, Slovenia, last week, ahead of Sunday’s runoff election.
item.description: With over 90 percent of the votes counted, the challenger, Marjan Sarec, congratulated President Borut Pahor for winning a second term.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK

item.title: N.F.L. Picks: Redskins Over Vikings; Patriots Over Broncos
item.media:description: Aaron Donald of the Los Angeles Rams leads a defense that deserves more credit for the team’s success than it has received.
item.description: The Los Angeles Rams, Dallas Cowboys and New England Patriots all seem primed for wins, but there is a quarterback controversy brewing in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN HOFFMAN

item.title: Trump Administration Guiding Health Shoppers to Agents Paid by Insurers
item.media:description: An insurance agent met this month with people shopping for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act in Miami.
item.description: After cutting funds for nonprofits that help people obtain coverage under the Affordable Care Act, the government is encouraging the use of insurance agents and brokers.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT PEAR
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Marib Journal: As Yemen Crumbles, One Town Is an Island of Relative Calm
item.media:description: A school in Marib, Yemen. Marib is a relative bright spot in a nation that has seen very few in recent years.
item.description: Years of war have devastated much of Yemen, but a combination of oil wealth and security have allowed Marib to grow.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: The Neediest Cases Fund: Her Secret to a Long Life? ‘It’s Good to Work a Lot’
item.media:description: Bella Pevzner, 89, at home in Brooklyn. As a teenager, she fled her home country of Belarus after the Nazis invaded it.
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.description: As a teenager, Bella Pevzner fled Belarus after the Nazi invasion. She worked well into her 70s, and at 89, she is applying her dogged work ethic to her paintings.
item.dc:creator: JOHN OTIS
item.category: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

item.title: Modern Love: What Love Looks Like
item.media:credit: Daniel Arnold for The New York Times
item.description: We set out to find couples in New York who would be willing to have their photo taken and to answer some personal questions. Here are 10 couples who agreed.
item.dc:creator: VALERIYA SAFRONOVA and DANIEL ARNOLD

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: On ‘The Good Doctor,’ the Anti-Antihero Is In
item.media:description: Freddie Highmore in “The Good Doctor” on ABC.
item.description: A decade after the rude genius of “House,” ABC’s sentimental hit drama focuses on the “care” part of health care.
item.dc:creator: JAMES PONIEWOZIK

item.title: Kenneth MacMillan’s School of Ballet Sex, Neurosis and Grit
item.media:description: Kenneth MacMillan rehearsing with the Sadler’s Wells Theater Ballet in the 1950s.
item.description: A London celebration provided a chance to think about MacMillan’s reputation and legacy 25 years after his death.
item.dc:creator: ROSLYN SULCAS

item.title: Cancer Doctors Cite Risks of Drinking Alcohol
item.description: Drinking alcohol, even modest amounts, increases the risk of breast cancer and other cancers.
item.dc:creator: RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: The Fix: Making Space for a Home Office
item.media:description: Start by making a list of everything you need to work happily at home — whether that’s an abundance of storage space or natural light, as in this office designed by Vanessa Alexander.
item.description: The best workspaces blend seamlessly into their surroundings — and reflect the personalities of the people who use them.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE HIGGINS

item.title: A Lesson From the Biggest Losers: Exercise Keeps Off the Weight
item.media:description: Dr. Jennifer Kerns, an obesity specialist and former contestant on the “Biggest Loser” television show, co-authored a study that has found exercise is essential to keeping weight off.
item.media:credit: Greg Kahn for The New York Times
item.description: Physical activity made all the difference to participants who managed to keep the pounds from returning, a new study finds.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA
item.category: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

item.title: The Look: Eternal Youth in Tompkins Square Park
item.media:description: Atticus Jones, 19 and Lola Daehler, 19 in Tompkins Square Park.
item.media:credit: Daniel Weiss for The New York Times
item.description: The photographer Daniel Weiss found versions of his teenage self in the East Village of Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL WEISS, THEODORE BARROW and EVE LYONS

item.title: For ‘Saturday Night Live,’ No Shortage of Targets, Including Louis C.K. and Roy Moore
item.media:description: Mikey Day as Roy S. Moore and Beck Bennett as Vice President Mike Pence, who is trying to convince him to drop out of the Alabama Senate race.
item.description: The sexual misdeeds of prominent men gave “S.N.L.” plenty of topical grist. But some of the accused came in for tougher treatment than others.
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF

item.title: Rap Disrupted Music First. Now It’s TV and Film.
item.media:description: Questlove, the drummer of the Roots, remembers an unfinished skit from “Chappelle’s Show” based on a song by the rapper Nas.
item.media:credit: Driely Schwartz Vieira for The New York Times
item.description: Questlove, Salamishah Tillet and Jon Caramanica discuss depictions of rap’s old-school days as well as new series and movies with hip-hop embedded into their frameworks.
item.dc:creator: QUESTLOVE, SALAMISHAH TILLET and JON CARAMANICA

item.title: In Catalonia, a Church Becomes a Place of Artistic Pilgrimage
item.media:description: An interior view of St. Victor as it prepares to reopen to the public after three years. In this section, overlooking the altar, the muralist Santi Moix included verses by the Catalan poet Josep Vicenç Foix.
item.description: The muralist Santi Moix has completely transformed the 1,100-year-old St. Victor — joining the list of contemporary artists remaking religious spaces.
item.dc:creator: KATIE CHANG

item.title: Where to Go Now: Finally, You Can Have Breakfast at Tiffany
item.media:description: The Blue Box Café at the flagship Tiffany & Co. store in New York City.
item.description: Tiffany & Co. opened the first-ever café at its flagship New York store, where visitors can now have breakfast and channel Audrey Hepburn.
item.dc:creator: JOHN L. DORMAN

item.title: The New Old Age: No Excuses, People: Get the New Shingles Vaccine
item.description: Shingrix, which begins shipping this month, is far more effective than the previous shingles shot. Experts recommend it for everyone over age 50.
item.dc:creator: PAULA SPAN
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Get Lost in a Giant Bamboo Labyrinth
item.description: The Labirinto della Masone, in Parma, Italy, is a dream come true of the Italian publisher Franco Maria Ricci, who set out to build the largest labyrinth in the world.

item.title: In Search of Silence
item.media:description: Erling Kagge in the gardens at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields. His first stop on a quest to find silence.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: A Norwegian explorer seeks one of New York's most elusive commodities.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN KURUTZ

item.title: Voices: A Gay Husband, a Dire Diagnosis and the Best-Laid Plans
item.description: I was just as unprepared to hear my doctor say “lung cancer” as I had been to hear my husband say “I’m gay.”
item.dc:creator: DANIELLE PERESS, M.D.

item.title: The Interpreter: What Explains U.S. Mass Shootings? International Comparisons Suggest an Answer
item.media:description: Outside the First Baptist Church of Sutherland Springs, Tex., after a mass shooting on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Callie Richmond for The New York Times
item.description: Americans advance a lot of theories for why they have so many more gun deaths than other countries do. The answer is lying in plain sight.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER and JOSH KELLER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Anniversary of the Apocalypse
item.media:description: Donald Trump on election night, a year ago Wednesday.
item.description: The once-unthinkable is becoming ordinary.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE GOLDBERG
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: At the Met Opera, a Note So High, It’s Never Been Sung Before
item.media:description: Audrey Luna, with (background, from left) John Tomlinson, Frédéric Antoun and David Adam Moore in “The Exterminating Angel” at the Metropolitan Opera.
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.description: It’s an A above high C — the equivalent of a pole vault to the sun. Few performers can hit it, but it’s a requirement in “The Exterminating Angel.”
item.dc:creator: ZACHARY WOOLFE

item.title: Air Travelers Resisting the ‘Incredible Shrinking Airline Seat’
item.media:description: Passengers aboard an Allegiant Air flight. Many small and large carriers have been finding ways to put more, smaller seats in cabins.
item.media:credit: Joe Giron for The New York Times
item.description: Thinner, smaller airline seats have allowed carriers to squeeze in more passengers. But travelers have begun to rebel against reduced legroom, citing safety.
item.dc:creator: MARTHA C. WHITE
